publicationStmt.p: File created by Evolving Hands project, Newcastle University

div.ab:
Received
Oct
October
11 1921
Baghdad
Sep.
September
11 .
1921
Darling Father . Few letters have had a greater success than your
message of congratulation telegraphed to Middlesbrough + posted from there.
Sir Percy + I gloated over it - it was the first, the very first sign that
anyone takes taking interest in us + our affairs. Sir Percy has had
several congratulatory telegrams from Mr Churchill but the public
knows nothing + no one seems to inform them. We search the
papers in vain for any trace of the masses of information we send
home, + all we find is letters from gentlemen who protest that
the Arabs would only be too thankful if we cleared out. I really
think
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
might do a little propaganda on our behalf. Anyhow, as
I say, your message had an unexampled success.
Meantime I also have your letters of
Aug August
2 + 10 + Mother 's
of
Aug August
3. The most interesting news is about Hugo - I do hope I
shall soon hear a fortunate ending to that romance. Then
the poor little Stockdale boy - I hope he has recovered
+ finally your striking appeal for industry + thrift + your
tale of municipal taxation in Poplar which is indeed a
matter for thought. As for Sir E. Geddes + the Committee of
Business Men - is the
Govt Government
off its head or what?
And now let me return to our affairs - no, before I do
so I must tell you how sad I feel about Hanagan . It
was clearly best, but he was a great figure in our Rounton
life - irreplaceable. I'll write to him.
I left off last week in the agonies of Cabinet making
- they're over; Faisal 's first Cabinet is formed. On the
whole we're well satisfied. Out of the 9 Ministers, 6 are
eminently capable men, well-fitted for their job. All
but 2 of these were in the Provisional
Govt Government
. The two new men
are Naji Suwaidi (Justice) perhaps one of the ablest, of the
younger generation, + a
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
who takes Education in
place of another Shi ah - I don't think there's much to
choose between him + his predecessor but capable Shi'ah
grow on very few bushes. An excellent addition to the

Cabinet is an exceptionally energetic + well trained
Xian Christian
doctor of Mosul who becomes Minister of Health, a
new portfolio. I must tell you in confidence that
he is my appointment. I brought him forward to Sir Percy
+ suggested making a Health Ministry - everyone is delighted
but of course they don't know it was I who did it.
Finally the fearfully, debatable question of the Interior
has been settled by the appointment of one Haji Ahmad
Ramzi who is outside all parties. He is so much outside
everything that not one of us (British officers) had ever
seen him or so much as heard his name. Faisal made
a shot in the dark + chose him because he has a
universal reputation for absolute honesty + integrity. He is
a very pious Moslem + spends one night every week
praying in the Naqib 's mosque. He has had some administration experience. During the last ten days,
since his name has been on the tapis, I've been hearing
many stories of him. Husain Afnan told me that one day
a lot of people were sitting in his office + the talk
turned, of course, on the Ministry of the Interior. "Who
is Haji Ramzi?" said one, + a mild voice answered: "I am."
I asked Faisal what Haji Ramzi said when he asked him to
take the office. "Nothing" said Faisal. "Nothing at all. I
told him to go round to see Mr Cornwallis (Advisor to
Interior) expecting that he would come back + discuss
matters with me, but he never returned." "Ah well"
said Rustam Haidar . "I can tell you something he
said. When he came out of
Y. M. Your Majesty
's room he passed through
the Secretaries' room, + he stopped by my table +
said. 'This is a very heavy job they have laid on my
shoulders.'" Also ally I heard that a day before the
appointment was announced some lot 20 of pro-Turks, men
on pensions, came to him + tried to frighten him into
refusal. Tomorrow the Turks might come back, or Saiyid

2
Talib , claiming his old post - what would Haji Ramzi do
then? Haji Ramzi appears at least to have known what to
do now. He rose in his wrath + said he wasn't yet appointed
+ anyhow it wasn't their affair, he would be obliged if
they would clear out of his house + not darken its
doorway again.
Last of all I myself went to see him this Sunday morning,
immediately after breakfast to offer my congratulations +
those of Sir Percy . I found a spare, shy little man, with
a thin beard turning grey + a very sweet expression,
sitting in a tiny house with a few people round him
whom I had never seen before. The talk rested with
me, Haji Ramzi making politely nervous replies. I can't
say I was very brilliant either, but perhaps it was just
as well I wasn't. Anyhow I hope he thought I was
cordial, for I felt cordial. I arranged for him to come
+ see Sir Percy + I wonder which of them will do the talking!
I assisted yesterday morning at the formal announcement from
the King to the Naqib , appointing him Prime Minister. The Naqib,
darling old thing, thought it would interest me, so he invited
me to be present. It took place in his house on the river bank.
Mr Garbett , Mr Cornwallis + I were the British representatives.
We arrived + found all the Naqib's male relations, sons,
brothers, cousins + nephews in the antechambers; he had
summoned them all up + a very imposing gathering they
made. The Naqib, dressed in his usual white, was sitting
in his white audlence room + with him three of the
ministers who were retaining office in the new Cabinet,
one of them being Sasun Eff . We sat for a little talking to
the Naqib, who was in the highest spirits. He asked
after you + informed the company that you + he were the
same age. Then Saiyid Mahmud , the eldest son, came in

+ announced the King 's delegation. In came Rustam Haidar
carrying Faisal's
farman Sovereign's edict.
in a green silk wrapping, followed
by Fahmi Mudarris + two of the
A.D.C. aide-de-camp
s. Rustam unwrrapped
the Farman laid it on his forehead + read it out. ["From the Queen to the
Duchess" said I to myself, most irreverently, for it was
really a very dignified little ceremony.] We all stood up
while it was read + while Saiyid 'Asim read his father's
reply accepting office. The Naqib , standing rather bowed in
his white robes, looked a very wonderful figure: at the
end he lifted his head + wished the King long life. One
by one, Rustam leading, we then went up to him, saluted him
+ offered our congratulations. That done, we sat down,
drank coffee + sherbet, chatted a little + took our leave.
'Iraq is a small place + its Prime Minister may not
loom very importantly in the world; nevertheless we were
making history.
Over Cabinet making I've got this week more deeply inside
the minds of Faisal's small band of devoted followers
than I've ever got before + I think I understand their
point of view. There are not very many of them, the
fervent patriots whose personal devotion to Faisal
is enhanced by the assurance conviction that he alone has
the qualities out of which an Arab King can be made,
a King who will unite the Arabs + take his plan among
the rulers of the world. Ja'far + Nuri are to my mind
the most striking examples + I love them both. What
they fear is the return of the Turks, by intrigue rather
than by arms. They know well that there is little genuine
Arab patriotism here, that the long tradition of
obedience to the Turks is difficult to eradicate + that
everyone who doesn't get a job is bound to be a pro-Turk.

3.
They think some turn of the wheel in Turkey may bring the
Committee of Union + Progress back to power (indeed nothing
is more probable) + that it will make a strong appeal to
all the former
C.U.P Committee of Union and Progress
men here. If those men are
holding the highest offices of state they might be able to do
incalculable harm to the Arab cause, therefore however
able they may be, however well-instructed, my little group
of friends will oppose + has opposed their appointment
to posts of the greatest responsibility. They are not to be
actually in the Cabinet + they are not to hold administrative
posts in Mosul , which is the gate, nor, if possible,
in Baghdad which is the forge of politics. That is why
they opposed Taufiq al Khalidi whom Faisal thought of as
a possible Minister of Interior; he has how been suggested
as
Mutasarrif Governor of an administrative district
of Baghdad but I believe they will oppose
that too + propose that he should be posted to
Nasiriyah where he can't get into touch with the Turks.
I objected to Nuri , when he was explaining what he
thought of Taufiq, that danger lay not only in Turkish
leanings but also in the insanity of their own extremists.
"Not nearly such grave danger" he said. "As long as
they are Arab in feeling they don't matter. Sidi Faisal
knows how to deal with them; they will disappear."
And upon my soul I think he is right. As they point
out it is not as if we proposed to remain in
military occupation. In a year, perhaps in 6 months,
there will be no more than 4 battalions of our
soldiers in the land. Then the patriots must guard
themselves, + they can't risk being stabbed in the back.
Faisal has got into his new house, on the river above
Baghdad. It's small but it's really very nice. On
Wed Wednesday
. one

of the
ADC aide-de-camp
s telephoned to me + asked me to dinner, en famille , so
to speak. I went up by launch. Have I ever told you what
the river is like on a hot summer night? probably not
- it can't be told at all adequately. At dusk the mist hangs in
long white bands over the water; the twilight fades + the lights of
the town shine out on either bank, with the river, dark + smooth
+ full of mysterious reflections, like a road of triumph through
the midst. Silently a boat with a winking headlight slips down
the stream, then a company of
quffahs Type of round boat used on the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.
, each with its tiny
lamp, loaded to the brim with watermelons from Samarra .
"Slowly, slowly!" the voices of the quffahjis drift across the water.
"Don't ruffle the river lest we sink - see how we're loaded." And
we slow down the launch so that the wash may not disturb them.
The waves of our passage don't even extinguish the floating
votive candles, each burning on its minute boat of made out
of the swathe of a date cluster, which anxious hands launched
above the town. If they reach the last house yet burning, the
sick man will recover, the baby will be born safely
into this world of hot darkness + glittering lights,
bewildering reflections. Now I've brought you out to where the
palm trees stand martialled along the banks. The water
is so still that you can see the scorpion in it, star
by star; we'll go gently past these quffahs - + here are
Faisal 's steps.
And you still can't form the remotest conception of how
marvellously beautiful it is.
We had an extremely amusing dinner, Faisal + I,
Nuri , Rustam + an
ADC aide-de-camp
. Faisal recounted his
experiences in London . When he arrived there after the
French turned him out of Syria , he went to the
F.O. Foreign Office
+ saw
Sir John Tilley , whom he rightly described as Meskin, a
harmless individual. Sir John told him he was going to

4 see the King , but he wasn't to talk about Syria , nor yet to mention
the French, + above all he wasn't to allude to the fact that
our agreements with the Arabs were incompatible with those
we had made with the French. Unfortunately they had
neglected to give the King the same directions + he embarked
at once on all the prohibited subjects, + ended by assuring
Faisal that he need have no anxiety because we were
solidly behind him. Then we talked of tribes + how to
guard our frontiers with camel corps - + it was
the greatest fun. I took Nuri home, for he lives on the river.
I also rode with Nuri on Friday morning; we went
down to breakfast with Haji Naji . It was then that he
told me what they felt about pro-Turks. And he told
me also lots of gossip about the Sharif 's family. The
3 sons by one mother, 'Ali , 'Abdullah + Faisal, of whom
'Abdullah was the favourite + Faisal always kept at a
distance + sent off to do the far-away jobs. When
their mother died, the Sharif married a Circassian
- they never have more than one wife. She
quarrelled bitterly with 'Ali over the management
of the household + 'Ali hates her son Zaid , whom
Faisal loves. Both 'Ali + 'Abdullah are terribly jealous
of Faisal now.
As we rode back through the gardens of the Karradah
suburb where all the people know me + salute me as
I pass, Nuri said "One of the reasons you stand out so
is because you're a woman. There are lots of political
officers but there's only one
Khatun Female title of nobility; counterpart to 'khan'.
. It is like when
Sidi Faisal was in London + always wore Arab
dress. There was no one like him. So for a hundred
years they'll talk of the Khatun riding by."

I think they very likely will.
It may have escaped your notice that we're in the middle
of
Muharram First month of the Islamic calendar.
. From the first to the fifteenth the
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
s
mourn for Husain , the Prophet's grandson, who was invited
over from Mecca by the 'Iraqis to be
Khalif The civil and religious leader of a Muslim state considered to be a representative of Allah on earth.
, + when
he arrived got no support from them, was opposed by the
armies of his rival Mu'awiyah at the place where
Karbala stands now, saw his followers die of
thirst + wounds + was killed himself on the I5th.
One small son escaped + from him Faisal is
descended. (So is the Naqib , for that matter.)
Incidentally, when Faisal came, that story of his
ancestor was always in my mind. The parallel
was so complete, the invitation from 'Iraq , the journey
from Mecca, the arrival with nothing but his personal
following - if the end has proved different it's
because I said " Absit omen !" so often.
Well, the Shi'ahs are mourning hard. It takes
the form of processions every night, lighted torches,
drums, beating of breasts. Some of the young men in our
office are conveniently lodged between the house of the
Persian Consul + the house of one of the
Nawab Viceroy
s - both
Shi'ahs - + they invited me to dinner on Friday to
see the processions. After dinner we sat on the roof
with the big courtyards of the Consul + the Nawab
on either side. Presently the wild drums drew near, the
glare of torches filled the sky + the processions
turned into the courtyards. Torches, + men leading
horses in gorgeous trappings, + men carrying huge
banners, + men with trays of lights on their
heads. And then a black-robed company which spread

5
out in two rows across the court + they were swinging
chains, with which they beat their backs - the black
robes were open to the waist at the back so that the
chains might fall on their bare skin. They swing them
very skilfully, with a little jerk at the top of the swing
so that the chains barely touched the skin, but the
effect was wonderful - the black figures in the glaring
torch light, swinging
rhythmically rythmically
from side to side with
the swing of the chains, + the drums marking the time.
Next came the breast-beaters, naked to the waist;
+ they stood in companies + beat their breasts in
unison to a different
rhythm rythm
of drums. Each procession
surged through the courtyards, swung their chains, beat
their breasts + surged out into the street; +
another followed it, interminably.
Having begun yesterday with the ceremony at the
Naqib 's, I spent the day in the office, rode after
tea with Mr Thomson + had an Arab dinner
party in the evening. My guests were Naji Suwaidi ,
loaded with blushing honours, Ja'far Pachahji , a
very nice creature, quiet + unobtrusive, Kadhim
Dajaili , a
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
whom I know well, + a certain
Sata' Beg al Hisri who was Faisal 's Minister
for Education in Syria + has just arrived
here. He is an
Aleppine From Aleppo
, a curious product. He is
a very well educated man, speaks French + a
little Italian. The thing he doesn't speak is Arabic -
he speaks it like a Turk. Turkish was the
official language, all his family spoke it, he

was brought up in Turkish schools + held office in
Constantinople . He says he only learnt Arabic a few
years ago, + he will never speak like an Arab.
Yet he's a pure bred Arab + purely Arab in
sympathy. He is married to a Turkish woman -
she was educated in an English school in
Constantinople + he says she speaks English
perfectly - not a world of Arabic, of course.
You can understand from things like this how
strong a hold Turkish tradition has.
Mr Glen of the Education
Dept Department
also dined
- we had very amusing talks about modern
Arabic + how to make a decent modern
literary language. Naji + Sata' carried
on the discussion mainly, the latter in
his amazing clipped speech with its sharp
Turkish vowels.
I really must stop. Your loving
daughter
Gertrude.
Hairwash very badly packed - only one
bottle intact. Nevertheless, herewith cheque.
I've been interrupted by having Ali Jaudat
Beg to call + a long talk about France +
the need of keeping quiet as to Syria .
You know these letters to you are my private diary.

I'm godmother to the little Bowman boy - would you be very kind + get a little
silver thing, not more than £5, for him + send to 17 Cambridge Sq.
His name is Paul Humphrey .

1921
Baghdad 11
Sep
September
1921
11
Oct
October
Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
ARAB BUREAU, BAGHDAD.
G L Bell
